text: In this video, you'll see how you can project

AWS Elastic Disaster 
Recovery (AWS DRS) costs.
With the AWS Pricing Calculator,

you can build detailed estimates for your
 disaster recovery solutions based on

expected usage to understand 
costs before implementation.

We’ll start on the AWS Pricing Calculator
page, where we'll create an estimate.

We'll search for the AWS Elastic 
Disaster Recovery service.
Let's configure the service.
First, we'll enter a description for the estimate.
Next, we’ll specify the Region.
For our purposes, we'll use US East.

Our estimate can include resources 
consumed both during data replication
and during launch drills or recovery.

We'll start with an estimate 
for replication services.
Next, we'll input our replication needs.

AWS DRS is billed hourly, per 
replicating server, at a flat rate,
plus replication infrastructure cost.

For this example, we have 10 
source servers involving 20 disks.

We'll estimate an average 
change rate of five percent per day.

Our total storage encompasses 
two terabytes of data.

Pricing varies according to staging 
volume, so we'll estimate a

percentage for how many of our source 
disks are larger than 500 gigabytes.

Volumes larger than 500gb default 
to more performant disk types.

Finally, you can select the number of 
days to retain the Amazon Elastic Block

Store (Amazon EBS) snapshots, in case 
you need to recover from older timeframes.

We'll use the default 
retention policy of seven days.
Let's finish the cost estimate.

At the bottom of the page, we can see 
a brief overview of the monthly cost.
Let's add this to our estimates.
The My Estimate page opens,

where we can see a tally of the 
estimated monthly and annual costs.

Now we'll build an estimate for drill 
and recovery costs. Let's add a service.
This time we'll search for Amazon EC2.
Let's add a description of the estimate.

We'll keep US East as the Region 
and use the “quick estimate” feature.

Next, let's adjust the 
Amazon EC2 specifications.

We'll keep Linux as the operating system, and
then search for the instance type by name.
We’ll select t3.small.
Here’s a breakdown of the cost per instance.
Let’s continue.
We’ll adjust the quantity of EC2 instances

needed to match the number we 
entered for the replication estimate.
Next, we'll select a pricing model.

Each option can be tuned to meet specific 
business needs and optimize costs.

For this example, let's build 
the estimate to account for only
on-demand drill launches.
We'll specify the expected utilization

of Amazon EC2 Instances 
as 2 hours per month.

For the pricing strategy, we'll 
select On-Demand Instances.

Finally, let's choose the Amazon EBS 
volume storage type and storage amount.
Let's add this service to our estimate.
The My Estimate page now summarizes

the total monthly and annual costs 
for the two services we configured.

When we've completed our estimates,
we can export and share them.

You've just seen how you 
can project AWS DRS costs.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it's your turn to try.
